Interestingly, this correspondence between locally checkable proofs and multiprover interactive proof systems completely breaks down in the case of quantum proofs. To see why, let's try to make an instance of the k-local Hamiltonian problem into a two-prover interactive proof system in a similar manner as we did for instances of k-SAT. The natural idea would be to ask each player to hold a copy of the groundstate |Ψ . The referee would then choose one of the terms H i of the Hamiltonian at random, and ask the first prover to hand him the k qubits on which H i acts. He would then choose one of these k qubits at random, and ask the second prover to provide it. Upon receiving the qubits, the verifier can, either evaluate the energy of these qubits with respect to H i , or check consistency between the second prover's qubit and the matching qubit from the first prover's answer...or can he? There is a serious issue with this procedure of course, an issue we encountered many times before. Because of the possible presence of entanglement in the groundstate, it could be that the states held by cheating provers are very different (even just on k of the qubits) but, on any one qubit, they are identical: it is impossible to check consistency between each provers' "proofs" by a local procedure. 27 We are stuck -there does not seem to be a straightforward notion of a quantum multiprover interactive proof that would capture the qPCP, as formulated in Conjecture 1.4, as classical interactive proof systems capture the classical PCP. Nevertheless, our attempts provided a glimpse of a new model of interactive proofs, in which the provers may be entangled, which is of its own interest as it provides insights into the power of entanglement in proofs from a different perspective. Formally, the class MIP * was defined by Cleve et al. [59] as the class of languages that can be verified by a classical polynomial-time verifier with the help of two all-powerful, untrusted but non-communicating, quantum entangled provers. 28 What can be said about this class? Interestingly, the classical inequality MIP = NEXP does not carry any non-trivial implication for the power of MIP * , in neither direction . Indeed, the trivial inclusion MIP ⊆ NEXP does not carry over, as there is no a priori bound on the dimension, or complexity, of quantum strategies for the provers. The reason the converse inclusion NEXP ⊆ MIP does not carry over automatically can already be found in the work of John Bell in the 1960s [41] related to the EPR states mentioned in Subsection 2.1: while the quantum provers still do not communicate, they can use their entangled state to generate correlations (joint distributions on their answers to the verifier's queries) that cannot be simulated using shared randomness alone. In a recent result [62] Ito and Vidick showed that Babai et al.'s multilinearity test, a key test in the proof of MIP = NEXP, is robust to entanglement: the test remains sound even when executed with quantum provers. Using this they showed that NEXP ⊆ MIP * : allowing the provers to be entangled does not reduce the expressivity of the class.

But can it increase it? One of the most intriguing open questions about entanglement is to provide any upper bound on this class; The problem in providing such a bound is that even though 27 There are many other difficulties: for instance, we have no guarantee that, when asked for qubits i or j, the second prover actually sends us distinct qubits. An even more basic problem is that there is no quantum procedure that can compare two quantum states (even by acting globally) -such a procedure only exists for the case of pure, not mixed, states. 28 One could also consider the class QMIP * in which the verifier is also allowed to be quantum, and exchange quantum messages with the provers. However, it was recently shown that QMIP * = MIP * [60]. Just as for singleprover interactive proofs, in which QIP = IP [61], the use of quantum messages does not bring additional power in this setting.

the provers only exchange polynomially many bits with the verifier, no bound on the amount of entanglement that they are using is known; for all we know, they might need to use doublyexponentially many EPR pairs, or more.

Despite the difficulty in directly connecting the multiprover model to the quantum PCP conjecture as formulated in Conjecture 1.4, one may still be able to derive interesting results regarding qPCP from the study of MIP * . Such a result was recently derived by Vidick [34], obtaining a different quantum equivalent to the classical PCP theorem, using its formulation in terms of multiplayer games. Classically, this formulation states that it is NP-hard to determine whether some 2-player games (such as the k-SAT game described) can be won with probability 1, or at most some constant. Vidick proved that NP-hardness still holds even if the players are quantum and are allowed to be entangled. The proof builds on showing that the low-degree tests, used in the original proof of the PCP theorem [3,4] possess some "robustness" properties -are sound even when the provers are allowed to use entanglement.

div.head: Concluding remarks
div.p: This column is full of open problems, and so there is no need to repeat those. We highlight several problems not encountered in the text:

• QMA: Perhaps there is a better characterization of QMA that would make the qPCP conjecture more accessible? That the current formulation is not optimal might be hinted to by the fact that most questions on this class are still open (including the analogue of the Valiant-Vazirani theorem [63], the question of whether one sided and two sided errors are equivalent [64], etc).

• Quantum locally testable codes (qLTCs): A locally testable code (LTC) guarantees that if a word is very far from the code, a random local test will detect it with good probability (this is referred to as the code being "robust"). LTC codes such as the Hadamard and the long code have played a crucial role in the classical PCP proof [3,4]; their quantum version was defined in Ref. [36] were weak bounds on the robustness of any qLTC were given. Does a qLTC with constant robustness exist? The question can be shown to be tightly related to the NLTS conjecture [36]; however, its direct connection to qPCP is yet to be clarified, since as was explained at the end of Sec. 3.3, quantum error correction codes cannot be used in a straight forward manner for proving the qPCP conjecture.

• Efficient description of quantum states: Even if the NLTS conjecture holds, one would need a stronger version of it to be relevant for the qPCP: in fact, the qPCP requires that the low energy states of the output Hamiltonians cannot have an efficient classical description. Non-triviality of the states is not sufficient; see for example Refs. [65,31,37] which provide such efficient descriptions for non-trivial states. A major thread in quantum Hamiltonian complexity is finding efficient classical descriptions of quantum states via the notion of tensor networks, a particular graphical representation of vectors (or operators). Understanding the conditions under which such efficient descriptions exist is thus of high relevance.

• Entangled provers: As we saw in Sec. 5.2, the tight connection that exists in the classical setting between locally checkable proofs, constraint satisfaction problems and multiprover interactive proofs breaks down in the quantum setting: locally checkable proofs can no longer be consistently shared between two provers. Although the formal connection seems to be lost, it may nevertheless be fruitful to examine questions on the one aspect in light of progress on the other. Does the recent proof [62] that NEXP ⊆ MIP * have any implications for qPCP? Could it be that QMA EXP , the exponentially scaled-up analogue of QMA, is included in MIP * ? Indeed, no upper bounds on the latter class are known -none at all.

div.head: The two-provers angle
div.p: We concentrate on an idea which played a very important role in the path towards the PCP theorem, its direct correspondence with multiprover interactive proofs. To see the connection, let us take the example of k-SAT (though any k -CSP would do). The PCP theorem implies that any k-SAT formula ϕ can be transformed into another formula ϕ over polynomially many more variables such that, if ϕ is satisfiable then so is ϕ , but if ϕ is not satisfiable then at most 99% of the clauses of ϕ can be simultaneously satisfied. Hence there is an efficiently verifiable proof for the satisfiability of ϕ: simply ask for an assignment to the variables of ϕ satisfying as many clauses as possible. The verifier will pick 200 clauses at random, read off the corresponding at most 200k variables from the proof, and accept if and only if the assignment satisfies all 200 clauses.

We can make this proof checking procedure into a two-prover interactive proof system as follows: the verifier chooses a clause of ϕ at random, and asks a first prover for an assignment to its variables. He also chooses a single one of the variables appearing in the clause, and asks the second prover about it. He accepts if and only if the first prover's answers satisfy the clause, and the second prover's answer is consistent with the first. It is this consistency check that allows to relate any strategy of the provers to a proof: since the second prover only ever gets asked about single variables, his strategy is an assignment to the variables.
